p.s: Though just having got to know eachother, Juliet and Romeo, the protagonists of William ShakespearesWilliam Shakespeare's Romeo and Juliet, have a strong love for eachother wichwhich they do not hold back to express and confess to eachother making vows and promises.
ThereTheirthougtsthoughts and feeling of love and greatly delivered through the language used in his play.
The first sign of their love is from line 58 to line 60 and also 61.
By stating My ears have not yet drunk a hundred words of that tounge'stongue's utterance, yet iI know the sound: art thou not Romeo and a Montague.
Although not directly speaking at love this metaphor states how she still recognizes Romeo, only by his voice, because of the dark.
Juliet recognizing him despite only having spoken a few words to eachother shows how much he stayedhas stayed on her mind and how much she has thought of him.
Romeo's direct asweranswer Neither, fair saint, if either thee dislike shows how he would even give up his own name and also family name, if Juliet, by any means, does not like either of them.
This is a great example of how much Romeo is willing to sacrifice for their love.

AsweringAnsweringJuliet's question of how he climbed the high walls of their garden, Romeo says: With love's light wings did I o'er perch these walls; For stony limits cannot hold love out and what love can do that dares love attempt(ll. 66-68).

Shakespeare firstly uses the phrase loves light wings as a metaphor for the lightness and feeling of freedom that come with being in love that make one feel like they can accomplish anything and that led him to climb the dangerous walls of the Capulet garden.
By stating For stony limits cannot hold love out Shakespeare makes Romeo refer back to the garden walls, he just defeated as a metaphor for anything in their love's way, even the families' feud.
This adds to the effect of Romeo being maniacally in love to a point where he even thinks he is invincible.

His thought of being invincible with Juliet's love is proven again in line 72 and line 73 as he states Look thou but sweet, And I am proof against their enmity wichwhich means that armed with Juliet's love and kindness he would not be in danger of Juliet's family's hostility.
During this part of their conversation Juliet is still very concerned of her family finding Romeo wichwhich she repeatedly expresses (ll. 65,70,74).

Romeothereforetherefor answers I have night's cloack to hidhide me from their sight (l. 75) as a metaphor the darkness giving him the opportunity to hide, but also And but thou love me, let them find me here: my life were better ended by their hate, than death prorogued wanting of thy love.

Romeo rather being dead and killed by the Capulets again adds to the effect and feeling of him being maniacally and blindly in love wichwhich intensified the watcherswatcher's connection to him and his love.
Yet again Romeo's love is visualized (l. 82-84): I am not a pilot; Yet wert thou as far as that vast shore wash'd with the farthest sea, I would adventure for such merchandise.
Comparing a treasure to Juliet and the farthest sea as anything standing in their love's way once again once can see that Romeo would do literally anything for Juliet.
Confirming what she just said in her monologue, Juliet want'swants to reassure that Romeo really loves her by telling him to pronounce it faithfully (l. 94).
This could be a sign of doubt in her mind, given everything Romeo just said to her and her still needing reassurement.
As Romeo begins to swear by the moon he is interrupted by Juliet: O swear not by the moon, that monthly changes in her circled orb (l. 109f).
For Juliet the moon is a metapher of inconsistency because of it'sits continiouslycontinuously changing shape.

She rather wants him to not swear at all; Or if thou wilt, swear by thy gracious self, Which is the god of my idolatry(ll. 113-115), with the last line implying that to her, Romeo is even godlike and then she'll believe him.

To sum it up, the audience gets to feel and see the intensity of Romeo and Juliet's love, going as far as willing to die for eachother and is given the opportunity to further sympathize with both characters, through the feeling of strogstrong love.
